trial_identification.studytitle: A Prospective Study to Investigate the Correlation between Wedged Hepatic Venous Pressure and Direct Portal Venous Pressure during formation or revision of Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients undergoing formation or revision of a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt, does the wedged hepatic vein pressure acurately reflect the direct portal venous pressure?

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: Measurement of wedged hepatic vein pressure. This involves wedging a balloon catheter in a hepatic vein branch and measuring the pressure. This is done immediately prior to the formation of the Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt. When the portal vein is accessed by the shunt, the direct portal vein pressure is measured. This will be compared to the initial hepatic vein wedge pressure measurements for the purpose of teh study. These measurements will add approximately 5 minutes to the scheduled procedure (which takes approximately 40 minutes in total)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Degree of correlation between wedged hepatic vein pressure and direct portal pressure. This will be assessed by measuring hepatic vein wedge pressures at multiple sites then measuring the direct portal venous pressure once the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt has been formed. The average of the wedged hepatic vein pressures will be compared to the direct portal vein pressure.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At time of formation or revision of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Age above 18 years Patient undergoing formation or revision of Transjugular Intrahepatic POrtosystemic Shunt Able to give informed consent

trial_design.concealment: All patients scheduled to undergo formation or revision of a Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt at a single centre will be invited to participate in the study.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Radiology Department Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Missenden Rd Camperdown NSW 2050

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Missenden Rd, Camperdown New South Wales 2050

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Missenden Rd Camperdown NSW 2050

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The intent of the study is to determine the accuracy of currently accepted methods of measurement of degree of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. This would primarily benefit patients indirectly and may lead to improvement in the techniques used to measure the severity of liver cirrhosis in the future.
